abstract.p: These are lecture notes for the 2014 Part III Algebraic Topology course taught by Dr. Jacob Rasmussen.

section.title: Introduction
section.p:
The recommended books are:
Algebraic Topology - Allen Hatcher,
Homology Theory - James W. Vick,
Differential Forms in Algebraic Topology - Raoul Bott and Loring W. Tu.

section.title: Homotopy

definition.title: Homotopic maps
definition.statement:
Maps f_0,f_1\colon X \to Y are said to be homotopic if there is a continuous map F\colon X\times I \to Y such that
F(x,0) = f_0(x)\text{ and }F(x,1) = f_1(x)\ \forall x\in X.

section.p: We let \Map(X,Y) = \{f\colon X \to Y \text{ continuous}\}. Then letting f_t(x) = F(x,t) in the above definition we see that f_t is a path from f_0 to f_1 in \Map(X,Y).

ol.li: X = Y = \RR^n, f_0(\overline{x}) = \overline{0} and f_1(\overline{x}) = \overline{x} are homotopic via f_t(\overline{x}) = t\overline{x}.

lemma.statement: Homotopy is an equivalence relation on \Map(X,Y).

notation.me: [X,Y] = \Map(X,Y)/\sim = \text{set of homotopy classes of maps } X \to Y.

lemma.statement: If f_0 \sim f_1\colon X \to Y and g_0 \sim g_1\colon Y \to Z then g_0\circ f_0 \sim g_1\circ f_1.

corollary.statement: For any space X the set [X,\RR^n] has one element.
corollary.proof: Define 0_X\colon X \to \RR^n by 0_X(x) = 0 \in \RR^n for any x\in X.

definition.title: Contractible space
definition.statement: X is contractible if 1_X is homotopic to a constant map.

proposition.statement: Y is contractible \iff [X,Y] has one element for any space X.
proposition.proof: (\Rightarrow) as in corollary. (\Leftarrow) [X,Y] has one element so 1_Y \sim a constant map.

section.p:
Given a space X how can we tell if X is contractible? If X is contractible then it must be path connected for one.
Contractible implies that [S^0, X] has one element and so f \colon S^0 \to X extends to D^1, and therefore X is path connected.
Similarly if [S^1, X] has more than one element then X is not contractible.

definition.title: Simply connected
definition.statement:
We say X is simply connected if [S^1, X] has only one element.
We say two space X and Y are homotopy equivalent if there exists f\colon X \to Y and g\colon Y \to X such that g\circ f \sim 1_X and f\circ g \sim 1_Y.

example.p: X is contractible if and only if X \sim \{p\}.
example.proof: X contractible \implies 1_X \sim c, a constant map. Choose f\colon X \to \{p\}, f(x) = p and g\colon\{p\} \to X, g(p) = c. Then g\circ f = c \sim 1 and f\circ g = 1_{\{p\}}. Converse: exercise.

section.exercise: If X_0 \sim X_1 and Y_0 \sim Y_1 then [X_0, Y_0] and [X_1, Y_1] are in bijection.
section.p: Given X and Y how can we determine if X\sim Y? How do we determine [X,Y]? For example is S^n \sim S^m.

section.title: Homotopy groups

definition.title: Map of pairs
definition.statement:
A map of pairs f\colon (X, A) \to (Y, B) is a map f\colon X \to Y with sets A\subset X and B\subset Y such that f(A)\subset B.
If we have maps of pairs f_0, f_1\colon (X,A) \to (Y,B) then we write f_0\sim f_1 if there exists F\colon(X\times I, A\times I) \to (Y,B) such that F(x,0) = f_0(x) and F(x,1) = f_1(x).

definition.title: Homotopy groups
definition.statement: If *\in X then the nth homotopy group is \pi_n(X, *) = [(D^n, S^{n-1}) \to (X, \{*\})].

section.p:
We now note several properties of this definition:
\pi_0(X, *) = set of path components of X.
\pi_1(X, *) is a group.
\pi_n(X, *) is an abelian group.
\pi_n is a functor \left\{ \begin{subarray}{l}\text{pointed spaces} \\ \text{pointed maps} \end{subarray}\right\} \to \left\{\begin{subarray}{l} \text{groups}\\ \text{group homomorphisms}\end{subarray}\right\}.
